title: US and Turkey reach agreement to suspend military operation in Syria
text:

The US and Turkey have reached an agreement to suspend military action in Northern Syrian for five days.

Donald Trump confirmed the news on Twitter and said that "millions of lives would be saved".

According to early reports following a meeting between the US delegates in Ankara with President Recep Erdogan, the Turkey government got "exactly what (they) wanted."

US Vice President Mike Pence said Turkey had agreed to a ceasefire to allow YPG Forces - which are predominantly made up of Kurdish fighters - to leave Northern Syria.

Relations between the US and Turkey have seemed frayed since the Trump White House decided to pull American forces out of Syria.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: Getty Images)

Within days of the shock decision Mr Erdogan had ordered his troops to invade the war torn country.

The Turkish military operation would end once the withdrawal was complete, Pence told a news conference.

"Today the United States and Turkey have agreed to a ceasefire in Syria," he said after more than four hours of talks at the presidential palace in Ankara.

"The Turkish side will pause Operation Peace Spring in order to allow for the withdrawal of YPG forces from the safe zone for 120 hours.

"All military operations under Operation Peace Spring will be paused, and Operation Peace Spring will be halted entirely on completion of the withdrawal."

Pence said U.S. forces in the region had already begun to facilitate a safe disengagement of YPG units.

The deal struck with Erdogan also provided for Turkey not to engage in military operations in the flashpoint Syrian border town of Kobani.

(Image: via REUTERS)

Yesterday a letter sent from Mr Trump to his Turkish counterpart urged him not to be a "tough guy" or a "fool".

The correspondence, which was littered with exclamation marks, reportedly found its way from Mr Erdogan's hand and into the bin.

The US has faced intense criticism for the withdrawal of troops, which critics say gave Turkey the green light to launch the military attack.

In recent years, the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) alliance has been a critical ally to the US in the fight against the Islamic State (IS) group in Syria.

(Image: REUTERS)

There are fears that the destabilisation of northern Syria could lead to a jihadist resurgence.

Turkey claims that the YPG is an extension of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), which is fighting for Kurdish autonomy in the region.

The philosophy that underpins the groups 40 year struggle is the idea that the stateless Kurds should be afforded a sovereign state partitioned from areas in Turkey, northern Iraq and Syria.

Yesterday Mr Trump claimed that the PKK were "probably" a bigger "terrorist threat" than IS.

"Now the PKK, which is part of the Kurds, as you know, is probably worse at terror, and more of a terrorist threat in many ways than ISIS," he said referring to the group which has been designated a terrorist group by the US, EU and Turkey.

This comes just five years after the US directly funded the PKK in The battle for Kobanî, in which ISIS were pushed out of 350 Kurdish villages in Syria by the YPG.

According to the Syrian Network for Human Rights, PKK fighters killed 1,157 civilians in northern Syria from 2012 until September of 2019.

Of those, 203 were children and 47 people -- including two women and one child -- were tortured to death.

While the exact number of people killed by IS is not clear, it is far greater than those who died at the hands of PKK fighters.

On one day alone, IS led simultaneous incursions in al-Suweida governorate, killing at least 200 individuals and kidnapping 27 people.

Landmines planted by the group as they fled Raqqa pursued by US-led forces killed or injured 1,000 people between October 2017 and the following April.
description: US President Donald Trump claimed millions of lives would be saved thanks to a ceasefire reached with Turkey President Recep Erdogan
